messages.content:
Summarize this: eon 2023 Accel/Mentorship Program Design 

INTERNAL ONLY 


Purpose / Objectives 
This program aims to increase the competitiveness, internationalization and financial resilience of early-stage start-ups in Lebanon through:
Accelerator track for ten early-stage social enterprises in Lebanon with sub-grants 
Mentorship track for 30 enterprises in Lebanon that are not receiving grants (Training for teams not in accelerator/sub-grant program) 


Metrics for Success 
10 sub-grants awarded to innovative initiatives 
8 out 10 startups in the accelerator with increased competitiveness (improved organizational capacity)
90 mentorship sessions to the 30 startups in the mentorship cycle
22 out of 30 startups in the mentorship track with increased competitiveness (improved organizational capacity)
5 out of 40 startups with increased access to finance  
Full details here: Bloom - M&E plan - SPARK (draft - shared)


Financials (Costs, Revenues) 
Revenues, pricing
$203,274.75
Costs
$4,000 for Trainers
$40,000 for Startups ($4,000 per startup)
Rest is for staff, office, and other admin


Team (People who will help make this happen, and their roles)
Programs Lead
Dara
Program Manager


Training Lead
Bilal
Training Manager
Habib
Mentor Manager
recruiting
Comms
Bana
Events
Steph
Community Manager
recruiting



PROGRAM OVERVIEW TO SHARE WITH POSSIBLE PARTNERS


Stakeholders / Target Participants 
Early Stage Social Enterprises (Stage 4)
Community, Knowledge and Ecosystem Partners 


Objectives / Expectations (for each stakeholder)
To join the program and grow on an individual and organizational level
To support in outreach and perks for the participants, to join in online events


The Pitch/Slogan/Messages
eon (Entrepreneurship Opportunities Nework, a program of the From Innovation to Creation project funded by the European Union in collaboration with Bloom and SPARK


Public Timeline
Date
Item
Thursday, April 6
Public Launch and Applications Open
Thursday, April 20
Open house starts (1 event per week)
Monday, May 15
Application deadline 
Monday, May 22
Enterprises are notified of selection into the sprint
Monday, May 29
Sprint starts
Tuesday, June 13
Sprint Demo day 
Tuesday, June 20
Enterprises are notified of selection into Accelerator or Mentorship
Monday, June 26
Accelerator and Mentorship starts
Tuesday, October 31
Demo day (Approximate Date)


Application/Filtering Process
Social enterprises operating in Lebanon for at least 3-5 years and already generating revenues.
More than one person in the team, with at least two team members working part-time in the enterprise.
No restrictions on sociographic or other parameters regarding the applicants.
Female-led enterprises and enterprises with higher diversity (age, gender, socio-economic background, etc.) are particularly encouraged to apply. 


Program Communications Tools
Email Newsletter
WhatsApp 
Social Media (LinkedIn, Instagram, Facebook, Twitter) 
Etc


Metrics for Success
How will you measure success? What defines success or failure, and at which time points? 
Same as above - I guess if we’re sharing this with partners, we can include them again

Basic Program Timeline
Detailed planning timeline here: Spark Accel Program Planning 
Phase
Timeline
Details
Program and activities alignment period (pre-launch) 
March
Work sessions to align on the details of the program structure, including the outreach (application form, comms material, etc.), the program, tools and assessments, the reporting details, and other program requirements as deemed necessary.
Outreach
Apr 6 to May 15
Curated outreach with a public campaign and series of events targeted to the enterprises while simultaneously spotting the ideal candidates and reaching out to them and inviting them to join the program if relevant.
Selection 
May 15-22
Reviewing applications against selection criteria and selecting enterprises for Sprint
Sprint
May 29 to June 13
A subset of eligible enterprises will be shortlisted to go through the sprint phase of the program.
Selection, onboarding, and Curriculum Design
June 14-30



Based on the scoring matrix, Bloom will select the enterprises for the accelerator program. The program manager and training manager will analyze the cohort’s assessment results to customize personalized learning journeys for the duration of the accelerator and source trainers for the digital library.
Accelerator
July 3 to Oct 27
Weekly training sessions and mentorship and grants
Mentorship
July 3 to Oct 27
Weekly mentorship sessions and support
Final Demo Day
Oct 31
Online or in-person
Post-Program 
Until Dec 31
Basic reporting from the enterprises’ progress for Bloom’s impact reporting requirements
Optional mentorship and networking

Selection of Participants for the Sprint
Based on the applications received, the Boom team will select a subset of enterprises that will participate in the Sprint. 
First, candidates that do not check all of the eligibility criteria will be disqualified. 
Eligibility:
Your enterprise is based in Lebanon
Your enterprise has been operating for at least three years and already generates revenues
Your enterprise is designed to be sustainable and economically viable.
Your enterprise has a social element / generates a positive social impact.
Alignment with SDGs
Tracking of social impact KPIs along with financial impact
Reinvesting at least half of revenues into social initiatives
You have the potential to sustain your enterprise without the program’s long-term support.
You have more than one person in the team, with at least two members working full-time in the enterprise.
No restrictions on sociographic or other parameters regarding the applicants.
Female-led enterprises and enterprises with higher diversity (age, sex, socio-economic background, refugee/host communities, location around Lebanon are particularly encouraged to apply. 
We are unable to support:
Enterprises of only one individual. 
Enterprises engaged with other entrepreneurship/innovation programs/accelerators unless there is a clear distinction between the program offerings. Enterprises can demonstrate that they have the time and capacity to join this program and their other program commitments.

Then, we will score the selection against the following scoring matrix (can also vary as per the program requirements:
Eligibility
Assessing whether the application fits the eligibility criteria of the program
YES / NO 
Team 
Assessing the team’s background, capabilities to execute, and ability to gain and contribute to the program. 
/ 10
Impact & Inclusion
Does the business have a social impact? Does it create jobs? Does it have a positive impact on marginalized and vulnerable communities? 
/ 10
Value Proposition
Is the Company tackling a real problem and offering a valuable solution? Does it have the ability to grow and be sustainable? Is the market potential attractive?
/ 10
Milestones & Traction
Does the business generate revenues? Has the business achieved significant milestones? Has the company demonstrated it could compete?
/ 5
Strategy & Challenges
Does the business have a clear growth strategy? Is the program able to support the business in its current challenges?
/ 5
Overall Passion
Based on the strength of the team,  the business, and the potential impact it can create: how passionate are you about this application?
/ 10

Program FAQ

Summary:

The eon 2023 Accel/Mentorship Program aims to support early-stage start-ups in Lebanon by offering an accelerator track for 10 social enterprises with sub-grants and a mentorship track for 30 enterprises without grants. The program's goals include increasing competitiveness, internationalization, and financial resilience. Success will be measured by the number of sub-grants awarded, improved organizational capacity, and increased access to finance among participating start-ups.

The program will involve stakeholders such as early-stage social enterprises and community, knowledge, and ecosystem partners. Key program events include public launch, open houses, application deadlines, sprints, accelerator and mentorship phases, and demo days. Participants will be selected based on eligibility criteria, including social impact, team strength, and potential for growth. The program will use various communication tools and follow a timeline that includes outreach, selection, sprint, accelerator, and mentorship phases, concluding with a final demo day and post-program reporting.

Summarize this:
Program FAQ  

What is the eon program?
The eon (Entrepreneurship Opportunities Network) program will bring training and mentorship support to 30 early-stage social enterprises in Lebanon in the Mentorship track and technical, financial, and mentorship support to 10 early-stage social enterprises in the Accelerator track to increase their competitiveness, internationalization and financial resilience.
The program is almost entirely remote/online and accessible to enterprises across geographies. Participating enterprises will grow their individual and organizational capacities through Bloom’s online platform, training pedagogy, networks of experts, and customized curriculum. 

What are the key dates:
Public Launch and Applications Open on Thursday, April 6
Open house starts on Thursday, April 20
The application deadline is Monday, May 15
Enterprises are notified of selection into the sprint by Monday, May 22 
Sprint starts on Monday, May 29
Sprint Demo day is on Tuesday, June 13
Enterprises are notified of selection into Accelerator or Mentorship by Tuesday, June 20
Accelerator and Mentorship Programs start on Monday, June 26
Demo day is on/around Tuesday, October 31.

What benefits do I receive from the program?
Funding to support an essential aspect of the business could improve growth and sustainability. Each enterprise in the Accelerator will get a $4,000 grant to support their needs and potential impact.
Training, mentorship, and other support during the four-month accelerator and mentorship program 
Lifetime access to Bloom’s resources and network of entrepreneurs, including mentors, investors, alums, and staff
Demo day exposure and other investor connections

How can we get funded after the program ends?
We provide the seed funding to get you going, but you may need more funding to continue your enterprise efforts. Near the end of the program, we’ll organize a Demo Day to help connect you with investors, funders, and organizations that could help you in the following stages of your enterprise journey. We’ll coach you so you’re as effective as possible and do everything we can to help get you follow-on support and funding. 

What language is content delivered in for the program?
The primary language in verbal and written communications during accelerator activities is English. However, we can also offer support and mentorship in Arabic or French. We may adapt those during the program to respond to the needs of enterprises. 

What is a typical day and week for a team during the program?
It’s your enterprise, so you’ll be hard at work on your business, the product, marketing, HR, etc. We’ll have between one and two weekly sessions, from formal workshops to informal discussions with our mentors, trainers, and guests. Some of those are “required,” but many are optional, and we expect enterprises to adapt and join the critical sessions for issues they’re dealing with in their enterprise. We’ll also regularly have required check-ins with each enterprise, usually every month. 
In general, though, you’ll be working on your enterprise each day, just like all of the other founders in the program. We don’t tell you what to do or when, but we create an environment conducive to helping your enterprise daily. And we’ll ensure you have many experienced mentors around to help you.

What kind of enterprises are we looking for?
We are looking for social enterprises that can positively impact multiple sectors. All are welcome to apply as long as their mission and objectives align with working toward the SDGs' achievement. We are looking for early-stage enterprises operating for at least three years and generating revenues. 

How do you choose which enterprises to accept into the program?
We will use the following criteria to assess eligible applications. These are not all requirements, but preferences and enterprises will be weighed on the different elements:
Impact: What difference your idea will make, and for whom, how many jobs you will create, and what sort of marginalized communities you will impact, and whether you align with the priority impact areas: culture, mindset, and education.
Capacity: What skills, knowledge, and resources do you have to develop and deliver your idea.
Feasibility: Whether you can realistically deliver your idea by the end of the program and within budget.
Sustainability: Whether your idea has the potential to become financially sustainable and last beyond the lifetime of the funding we provide.
Stage of Enterprise and Product: Whether the enterprise is already generating revenue and the stage of development of the specific product or branch that this program will support.
Inclusion and user testing: Whether the voices of your target clients have been included in the prototype/solution design, and whether your client base is inclusive of different demographics, backgrounds, sexes, etc.
Innovation and growth potential: Whether your idea is new and different, and where or how it can potentially grow.

What kind of enterprises is eligible for the program?
Your enterprise is eligible if it meets the following criteria:
Your enterprise is based in Lebanon
Your enterprise has been operating for at least three years and already generates revenues
Your enterprise has a social element / generates a positive social impact.
Alignment with SDGs
Tracking of social impact KPIs along with financial impact
Reinvesting at least half of revenues into social initiatives
You have the potential to sustain your enterprise without the program’s long-term support.
You have more than one person in the team, with at least two members working full-time in the enterprise.
No restrictions on sociographic or other parameters regarding the applicants.
Female-led enterprises and enterprises with higher diversity (age, sex, socio-economic background, refugee/host communities, location around Lebanon) are particularly encouraged to apply. 
We are unable to support:
Enterprises of only one individual. 
Enterprises engaged with other entrepreneurship/innovation programs/accelerators unless there is a clear distinction between the program offerings. Enterprises can demonstrate that they have the time and capacity to join this program and their other program commitments.

What stage of enterprises is eligible for the program?
Imagine a spectrum of entrepreneurship running from learning about the concept and skills to having a mature enterprise changing the world. Those stages are categorized as follows. For the sake of this challenge, we will focus on supporting enterprises as indicated in yellow below:

Enterprise Development Stages
Stages
Sub-Stages
0. LEARNING	
0.1. Learning without the goal of launching an enterprise
1. IDEATION
1.1. Want to start and looking for/testing ideas
2. IDEA-STAGE
2.1. Exploring ideas, conducting market/customer research 
2.2. Have started developing my idea
3. PROTOTYPE
3.1. Have an early (low-fidelity/paper) prototype (of product or service)
3.2.  Have a functioning (high-fidelity) prototype with early users / early adopters
4. EARLY-STAGE
4.1. Declining revenues and the enterprise is not yet profitable/sustainable
4.2. Revenues are stagnant or growing slowly, but the enterprise is not however profitable/sustainable
4.3. Revenues are growing quickly, but the enterprise is not yet profitable/sustainable
5. GROWTH-STAGE
5.1. Profitable/sustainable business (with stable, growing, or declining revenues)
5.2. Seeking scalability (of impact and/or profits)
5.3. Seeking diversification 
5.4. Seeking an exit 
5.5. Established national enterprise
5.6. Established multinational enterprise


What does the program look like?
You will get access to an empowering program that will include monetary prizes, mentoring, access to opportunities, and more.
Open House
Online discussions and “info sessions” with thought leaders to build awareness and momentum around the program. 
Selection process
Sprint
High-intensity two-week-long Sprint with workshops, mentorship, and support for all enterprises. 
1-on-1 follow-ups with the enterprises
Sprint Demo Day
Final selection
Track 1: Accelerator
Weekly or bi-weekly workshops adapted to the needs of the cohort and enterprises
Regular milestone check-ins with all enterprises
Mentorship coordination
Grant disbursement and support
Online or offline Demo Day, or otherwise optimized for the interests of partners and the needs of the enterprises to help the enterprises continue their growth path. 
Track 2: Mentorship
Monthly or twice monthly workshops and speaker series adapted to the cohort's and enterprises' needs
Regular milestone check-ins with all enterprises
Mentorship coordination
When you're done give me some thoughts on the eligibility criteria, our selection process, and the definition of innovation

The eon program is an initiative aimed at supporting early-stage social enterprises in Lebanon by providing training, mentorship, and financial assistance. It has two tracks: the Mentorship track, supporting 30 enterprises, and the Accelerator track, supporting 10 enterprises. Key dates include the application deadline on May 15 and the Demo Day on October 31.

Eligibility criteria for the program include having a Lebanon-based enterprise that has been operating for at least three years and generates revenue. The enterprise must also have a positive social impact, align with SDGs, track social impact KPIs, reinvest at least half of revenues into social initiatives, have the potential for long-term sustainability without the program's support, and have a team of at least two full-time members. Female-led and diverse enterprises are particularly encouraged to apply.

The selection process involves assessing applications based on impact, capacity, feasibility, sustainability, stage of the enterprise and product, inclusion and user testing, and innovation and growth potential.

Innovation, as defined by the program, refers to ideas that are new and different, with the potential for growth in various areas or contexts. The program emphasizes the importance of unique and creative solutions that can scale up and positively impact multiple sectors.

In summary, the eon program aims to support early-stage social enterprises in Lebanon that align with its eligibility criteria and selection process. The focus on innovation highlights the program's commitment to fostering new and unique ideas that can drive sustainable growth and create significant social impact.
can you give me different definitions of innovation that might match something Bloom.pm is inspired by?

Bloom.pm, as an organization supporting social enterprises, may draw inspiration from various definitions of innovation. Here are some alternative definitions that could resonate with their approach:

1. Incremental Innovation: This type of innovation refers to small improvements or upgrades in existing products, services, or processes, enhancing their value or efficiency without radically altering the core concept.

2. Disruptive Innovation: Disruptive innovation involves creating new products, services, or business models that disrupt established industries or markets, often making traditional approaches obsolete and paving the way for new market leaders.

3. Social Innovation: Social innovation focuses on creating novel solutions that address pressing social challenges and enhance the well-being of individuals and communities. This type of innovation often emphasizes sustainability, inclusiveness, and equitable access to resources.

4. Sustainable Innovation: Sustainable innovation combines the concepts of economic growth, social equity, and environmental protection. This type of innovation aims to develop products, services, or processes that minimize negative environmental impact and promote long-term social and economic benefits.

5. Open Innovation: Open innovation is a collaborative approach to innovation, in which organizations actively involve external partners, such as other companies, research institutions, or individuals, in their innovation processes. This model encourages knowledge sharing, co-creation, and the pooling of resources to generate new ideas and solutions.

6. Frugal Innovation: Frugal innovation involves creating cost-effective, efficient, and accessible solutions by optimizing resources and minimizing waste. This type of innovation often targets underserved markets or populations, providing affordable and practical solutions to meet their needs.

Bloom.pm may be inspired by one or a combination of these innovation definitions, depending on the specific goals and focus areas of their programs and the social enterprises they support.
what does the EU define as innovation and give several alternative ways to define innovation

The European Union (EU) defines innovation as the process of turning ideas into new or improved products, services, or processes that create value for society, the economy, and the environment. According to the EU, innovation can occur in various contexts, including business, public sector, and academia, and can involve different types of innovations, such as product, process, organizational, or social innovations.

Here are several alternative ways to define innovation:

1. Radical Innovation: This type of innovation refers to breakthroughs that fundamentally change the way products, services, or processes are designed, produced, or delivered. Radical innovations often involve new technologies or approaches and can significantly disrupt existing markets or industries.

2. Incremental Innovation: Incremental innovation focuses on making small improvements or adjustments to existing products, services, or processes. These changes may not be groundbreaking, but they can improve performance, efficiency, or customer satisfaction.

3. Architectural Innovation: Architectural innovation involves reconfiguring existing components, systems, or technologies in novel ways to create new products, services, or processes. This type of innovation builds on existing knowledge and resources but results in significant changes in the overall system.

4. Market Innovation: Market innovation refers to the creation of new markets or the redefinition of existing ones by introducing new products, services, or business models. This type of innovation can change the competitive landscape and create new opportunities for growth and value creation.

5. Technological Innovation: Technological innovation involves the development and application of new technologies, tools, or techniques that enhance the capabilities of products, services, or processes. This type of innovation can lead to increased efficiency, performance, or sustainability.

6. Business Model Innovation: Business model innovation refers to the development of new ways of creating, delivering, and capturing value within a company or industry. This type of innovation often involves rethinking traditional business practices or revenue models to better align with changing market conditions or customer needs.

These alternative definitions of innovation emphasize different aspects of the innovation process and can be applied to various contexts, industries, or organizations.
